newsitem.title: GERMANY: Turkish Airlines sees German cargo stronger.
newsitem.headline: Turkish Airlines sees German cargo stronger.

text.p: Turkish Airlines said it expected air cargo tonnage growth of 50 percent or more from southern Germany this year.
Osman Ersoy, managing director of E&P Cargo International, southern Germany wholesaler for the airline, said he expected to carry 2,500-3,000 tonnes in 1997.
Turkish Airlines flew 1,800 tonnes of airfreight on its twice-weekly B727-200 freighter flights between Istanbul and Nuremberg last year, he told Reuters in an interview.
"Since Turkey has been in the EU customs union volumes have increased a lot and there is strong demand," Ersoy said.
Textiles accounted for 95 percent of imports from Turkey while German exports included industrial spare parts, electronics and general mixed air cargo, he added.

The airline achieved load factors of between 70 and 95 percent for the 20 tonnes freighter capacity and was seeing growing interest for transshipment freight to destinations in the CIS states and Johannesburg, Ersoy said.
The main rivals for the German market were Lufthansa Cargo and Cargolux, he added. - Reuters Air Cargo Newsroom. Tel+44 171 542 7706 Fax+5017 - www.racs.com
